Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___

Chief Complaint:
Fall
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None 

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a ___ female w/ past medical history of HTN/HLD, 
CAD, L. hip fracture s/p ORIF and recent midbrain infarct now 
presenting s/p fall from sitting height. Per the pt's daughter 
she was trying to stand up without assistance from her 
wheelchair, lost balance and fell to her side striking her head. 
Of note, the pt has not been verbal or interactive since her 
recent stroke. Per phonecall w/ the patient's daughter, her 
mother's mental status has been declining over the last ___ 
weeks. She has been less interactive, spending large portions of 
her day sleeping; she previously had poor memory but enjoyed 
reading and telling stories. Pt also has been increasingly 
confused, occasionally unable to identify children which is new 
over the last week despite  
 Of note pt was recently admitted ___ - she presented w/ 
L. ptosis and gaze palsy and was found to have an acute L. 
midbrain infarct. This was thought to be cardioembolic in 
origin, though without definite source seen on TTE. Per 
discussion with the family, further workup for etiology of 
stroke was not pursued as per discussion w/ family they would 
not want anticoagulation. Cognitive impairment during this 
admission was thought to be long standing.  
 In the ED:  
 Initial vital signs were notable for: T 97.3, HR 88, BP 136/73, 
RR 16, 98% RA  
 Exam notable for:  
 "Gen: sleeping, opens eyes to sternal rub  
 HEENT: right temporal hematoma, PERRL, sclera anicteric  
 RESP: unlabored respirations, bilateral rhonchi likely ___ 
snoring, no crackles  
 GI: abd soft, LLQ tenderness to palpation w/o rebound/guarding, 
hypoactive bowel sounds  
 NEURO: unable to assess cranial nerves given MS"  
 Labs were notable for:  
 HypoNa 131  
 Leukocytosis 17.6 (Neutrophil ___ 80.4)  
 UA (straight cath) Lg leuk, pos Nitrite, 50 WBCs, few Bact  
 - UCX and BCx were drawn  
 Studies performed include:  
 CT A/P: Acute sigmoid diverticulitis, hyper enhancement and 
thickening of bladder wall is nonspecific, but can be seen in 
cystitis, Fibrotic changes at the lung base. It would be 
difficult to exclude superimposed acute aspiration, Severe 
compression fracture of the L1 vertebral body with retropulsion 
into the canal causing severe narrowing is chronic.  
 CT C-spine: No acute fracture.  
 CTH w/o contrast: Unchanged hypoattenuation in the left mid 
brain corresponding to acute to early subacute left infarct  
 CXR - no focal consolidation  
 Patient was given:  
 1L LR  
 Flagyl 500mg Q8 (s/p 2 doses)  
 Ciprofloxacin 400mg  
 ASA 81mg  
 Started on NS mIVF @ 100cc/hr  
 Vitals on transfer: T 96.4, HR 64, BP 110/56, RR 16, 99% RA  
 Upon arrival to the floor, pt is arousable and denies any acute 
complaints. Notably, she is only oriented to person and that she 
is in a hospital, she is unable to recall that she fell and hit 
her head, how many children she has, or where she lives. She did 
deny any current abdominal pain, dysuria, HA, dizziness or CP.

Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL 
===================
Vitals: Reviewed in OMR  
 GENERAL: Sleeping but arousable elderly woman - awakens to

 HEENT: R. temporal hematoma, R. cheek tenderness, L. pupil 
1.5mm, R. pupil .5mm , Complete L. ptosis, Severely limited 
adduction, abduction of L. eye. Sclera anicteric and without 
injection. MMM  
 NECK: Thyroid is normal in size and texture, no nodules. No 
cervical lymphadenopathy. No JVD.  
 CARDIAC: Regular rhythm, normal rate. Audible S1 and S2. No 
murmurs/rubs/gallops.  
 LUNGS: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rhonchi 
or rales. No increased work of breathing.  
 BACK: No spinous process tenderness. No CVA tenderness.  
 ABDOMEN: Normal bowels sounds, non distended, non-tender to 
deep palpation in all four quadrants. No organomegaly.  
 EXTREMITIES: No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. Pulses DP/Radial 
2+ bilaterally.  
 SKIN: Warm. Cap refill <2s. No rash.  
 NEUROLOGIC: CN2-12 intact. ___ strength throughout. Normal 
sensation. Gait is normal. AOx3.

Brief Hospital Course:
==================
SUMMARY STATEMENT
==================
___ is a ___ female w/ past medical history of HTN/HLD, 
CAD, L. hip fracture s/p ORIF and recent midbrain infarct now 
presenting s/p fall from sitting height who was admitted for 
diverticulitis and UTI, and will continue antibiotics through 
___. 

=====================
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES 
=====================
[] Cipro/Flagyl for diverticulitis and UTI through ___ 
[] Pt w/ intermittent urinary retention, if decreased urine 
output, please bladder scan and insert foley if not urinating 
and retaining 
[] Pt has had hyponatremia that has been slowly improving, 
please check a ___ 
[] Pt was started on metoprolol while inpatient for atrial 
fibrillation rate control, please get vitals daily to monitor HR 

[] Pt's blood pressure medications were increased, please 
titrate as needed for SBP goal < 150
[] Pt discharged with mild stable leukocytosis thought to be 
secondary to pt's resolving infection
[] L1 compression fracture noticed incidentally on imaging. Pt 
is asymptomatic. 

Discharge Hgb - 12.7 
Discharge Cr - .5 
Discharge Na - 134 

NEW MEDICATIONS
Apixiban 2.5mg BID
Amlodipine 5mg daily 
Atorvastatin 40mg QHS 
Metrondiazole 500mg Q8
Ciprofloxacin 500mg Q12 

MEDICATIONS WE CHANGED
Increase losartan to 75mg daily 

MEDICATIONS WE STOPPED 
Simvastatin 
Gabapentin 

===========================
HOSPITAL COURSE BY PROBLEM 
===========================

ACUTE ISSUES: 
=============
#Acute Sigmoid Diverticulitis
Pt presenting w/ LLQ pain on exam, leukocytosis to 17 and 
evidence of acute sigmoid diverticulitis on CT A/P .Leukocytosis 
and abdominal pain resolved, patient remain hemodynamically 
stable and she was transitioned to oral antibiotics. 
- Continue Ciprofloxacin/Flagyl PO for full 10 course through 
___ 

#Proteus vulgaris urinary tract infection 
#Urinary Retention
UA on admission w/ nitrites, large leukocytes, +bacteria 
suggestive of UTI. Pt intermittently endorsed dysuria, which has 
resolved. The course has been complicated by urinary retention 
which may be multifactorial secondary to recent stroke and 
mucosal irritation from urinary tract infection.
- Continue ciprofloxacin (P.vulagris sensitive) until ___ 

#Atrial fibrillation w/ RVR, paroxysmal 
On ___ pt was found to be in Afib w/ RVR and rates in the 
120s, this initially responded well to 25mg of PO metoprolol. 
She was thought to be possibly mildly hypovolemic and given 500c 
IVF. She reverted back to sinus rhythm w/ HRs in the ___ on 
___. She was started on apixaban 2.5mg daily for 
anticoagulation given high risk for recurrent cardioembolic 
stroke after discussion with family. 

#HypoNa 
Pt presenting with hypoNa to 131 on admission from previous 
discharge Na of 130. Etiology of this is still somewhat unknown. 
Given her mental status, possibly decreased PO intake and 
infection it was thought that she may be hypovolemic and her 
sodium responded intermittently to IVF. Her Na uptrended w/o 
intervention to 134 prior to discharge. 

#HTN/HLD 
Losartan held following previous admission to allow for 
permissive hypertension s/p stroke.. Pt had been hypertensive 
here with labile SBPs ranging from 120s-180s. Her losartan was 
restarted and titrated to 75mg daily. She was also started on 
amlodipine 5mg daily. 
- Despite recent stroke her blood pressure goal should be 
normotension, SBP <150 

#Fall 
Pt fell from sitting height had R. head strike, no LOC. No c/f 
for acute intracranial bleed on CTH. Etiology of fall is most 
likely mechanical ___ imbalance from chronic medical issues. 
- ___ consulted and recommending continued rehab 

CHRONIC ISSUES:
===============
#Recent L.Midbrain infarct 
Recent hospitalization for acute L.midbrin infarct, thought to 
becardiolembolic in origin (though no definite nidus on 
TTE),family did not want anticoagulation initially. However on 
repeat discussion with the family the decision was made to 
initiabe apixaban 2.5mg. Pt still w/ complete L.ptosis, minimal 
extraocular movement of left (no abduction or adduction), 
possible RUE weakness though difficult to assess given mental 
status. 
- Continued ASA 81 
- Simvastatin 40 switched to Atorvastatin 40 
- Increased Losartan as above 

#Dementia,
#Toxic metabolic encephalopathy 
Pt presenting w/ poor baseline cognition most likely 
representing chronic cognitive decline in the setting of known 
dementia. However, this may have been acutely worsened given 
recent recent infectious and vascular insults as above. Pt 
largely only oriented to person and location (ie. hospital) this 
admission. 

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Gabapentin 100 mg PO BID 
2. Simvastatin 40 mg PO QPM 
3. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  amLODIPine 5 mg PO DAILY  
2.  Apixaban 2.5 mg PO BID  
3.  Atorvastatin 40 mg PO QPM  
4.  Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H Duration: 4 Days  
5.  Losartan Potassium 75 mg PO DAILY  
6.  Metoprolol Succinate XL 100 mg PO DAILY  
7.  MetroNIDAZOLE 500 mg PO Q8H Duration: 4 Days  
8.  Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY  
9.  Senna 17.2 mg PO BID  
10.  Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY

Extended Care

Discharge Condition:

Level of Consciousness: Lethargic but arousable.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

Please see below for more information on your hospitalization. 
It was a pleasure taking part in your care here at ___! 

WHY WERE YOU ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL? 
- Because you fell and hit your head and were found to have an 
infection in your urine and your colon 

WHAT WAS DONE WHILE YOU WERE IN THE HOSPITAL? 
- You had a head CT that did not show any bleeding 
- You were given antibiotics for your infections 
- You were started on a blood thinner, apixaban, because you 
were found to have different heart rhythm called atrial 
fibrillation 
- We increased your blood pressure medications 

WHAT DO YOU NEED TO DO WHEN YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL? 
- Go to all of your appointments 
- Take all of your medications 

We wish you all the best! 
- Your ___ Care Team

NEW MEDICATIONS
Apixiban 2.5mg BID
Amlodipine 5mg daily 
Metrondiazole 500mg Q8
Ciprofloxacin 
Atorvastatin 40mg QHS 

MEDICATIONS WE CHANGED
Increase losartan to 75mg daily 

MEDICATIONS WE STOPPED
Gabapentin 
Simvastatin 

 
Followup Instructions:

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
